1.description: Used for habitual actions, general truths, and permanent situations
examples: The sun rises in the east
1.usage: Subject + base verb (add -s/-es for third person singular)

2.description: Used for actions happening now or temporary situations
examples: She is studying for her exam

3.description: Used for completed actions in the past
3.usage: Subject + past form of verb (regular: verb + -ed, irregular: special forms)

4.description: Used for ongoing actions in the past or interrupted actions
examples: I was working when you called

5.description: Used for actions completed at an unspecified time or continuing to present
examples: She has lived here for five years
They have never been to Japan

6.description: Used for actions that started in the past and continue to the present
examples: I have been working for three hours
She has been studying since morning
They have been waiting for you

7.description: Used for actions completed before another past action
examples: I had finished before you arrived
She had already left when I called

8.description: Used for future actions, predictions, and spontaneous decisions

9.description: Used for ongoing actions at a specific time in the future
examples: I will be working at 9 AM
She will be traveling next week
They will be discussing the proposal

10.description: Used for real or possible situations in the future
examples: If it rains, I will stay home
If you study hard, you will pass
If she comes, we will start
10.usage: If + present simple, will + base verb

11.description: Used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present/future
examples: If I were rich, I would travel
If she had time, she would help
If they knew, they would tell us
11.usage: If + past simple, would + base verb

12.description: Used for hypothetical situations in the past (impossible to change)
examples: If I had studied, I would have passed
If she had come, we would have started
If they had known, they would have helped
12.usage: If + past perfect, would have + past participle

13.description: Used when the focus is on the action rather than who performs it
examples: The book was written by Shakespeare
The project will be completed tomorrow
13.usage: Object + be + past participle (+ by + agent)

14.description: Used to express ability, possibility, or permission

15.description: Used to express necessity, obligation, or strong probability

16.description: Used to give advice, express obligation, or probability

17.description: Used to express possibility, permission, or polite requests

18.description: Essential clauses that define or identify the noun (no commas)
examples: The book that I bought is interesting
The person who called you is here
The house which we visited was beautiful

19.description: Additional information about the noun (with commas)
examples: My brother, who lives in London, is visiting
The book, which I finished yesterday, was excellent
Paris, where I was born, is beautiful
19.usage: Noun, + who/which + clause, + main clause continues

20.description: Used to report what someone said without using their exact words
examples: He said that he was tired
She told me she would come
20.usage: Reporting verb + that + reported clause (tense changes)

examples: He asked if I was ready
She wondered where they had gone
They inquired whether we needed help

22.description: Verb forms used as nouns or after certain verbs
22.usage: Gerund: verb-ing as noun; Infinitive: to + base verb

23.description: Used for specific, known, or unique things

24.description: Used for non-specific, singular countable nouns
24.usage: A + consonant sound; An + vowel sound

25.description: Used to compare things or show the highest degree
25.usage: Short adj: -er/-est; Long adj: more/most + adjective

26.description: Used to indicate when something happens

27.description: Used to indicate location or position

29.description: Questions with yes or no answers

30.description: Short questions added to statements for confirmation
30.usage: Positive statement + negative tag; Negative statement + positive tag

31.description: Nouns that can or cannot be counted individually
31.usage: Countable: a/an, many, few; Uncountable: much, little, some

32.description: Used to indicate quantity without being specific

34.usage: Few/little (negative meaning), A few/a little (positive meaning)

35.description: Used to show how often something happens

36.description: Used to describe how something is done

37.description: Verb + particle combinations where object can separate them
examples: Turn on the light / Turn the light on
Pick up the book / Pick the book up
37.usage: Verb + particle + object OR Verb + object + particle

38.description: Verb + particle combinations that cannot be separated

39.description: Subjects and verbs must agree in number (singular/plural)
39.usage: Singular subject + singular verb; Plural subject + plural verb

40.description: Using the same grammatical form for items in a series
examples: I like reading, writing, and swimming
She is smart, kind, and funny
40.usage: Keep same form: all gerunds, all adjectives, all infinitives, etc.

41.description: Words that connect equal grammatical elements
examples: I studied hard, so I passed the exam
41.usage: Independent clause + coordinating conjunction + independent clause

42.description: Words that connect dependent clauses to independent clauses
examples: I stayed home because it was raining
42.usage: Subordinating conjunction + dependent clause + independent clause

43.description: Used to show ownership or belonging
43.usage: Singular: noun + 's; Plural ending in s: noun + '; Irregular plural: noun + 's

44.description: Used to combine two words by omitting letters

45.description: Used to separate items in a series
examples: I bought apples, oranges, and bananas
45.usage: Item, item, and item (Oxford comma optional but recommended)

46.description: Used to separate clauses in complex sentences
examples: When I arrived, everyone was waiting
I was tired, so I went to bed
46.usage: Dependent clause first: comma after; Independent clauses: comma before conjunction

47.description: Rules for when to use capital letters
47.usage: First word of sentence, proper nouns, days, months, titles

48.description: Pronouns must clearly refer to specific nouns
examples: The book is interesting. It has great characters
48.usage: Pronoun must have clear antecedent; avoid ambiguous references

49.description: Modifying phrases that don't clearly modify the intended word
examples: Wrong: Walking to school, the rain started
Right: Walking to school, I got caught in the rain
49.usage: Modifier should be placed next to the word it modifies

50.description: Incorrectly joined independent clauses that should be separated
examples: Wrong: I went to the store I bought milk
Right: I went to the store, and I bought milk
50.usage: Use periods, semicolons, or coordinating conjunctions to separate independent clauses
